Polyunsaturated Fats: Omega-3 fatty acids in polyunsaturated fats can help reduce symptoms of depression.
Polyunsaturated fats support brain function and may improve mood regulation when feeling sad.
Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency has been linked to depression, so consuming it may help when feeling sad.
Vitamin D acts on receptors in regions of the brain that regulate mood and emotions.
Magnesium: Magnesium helps regulate neurotransmitters that influence mood and can reduce symptoms of sadness.
Low magnesium levels have been associated with increased depression and sadness.

Vitamin C: Vitamin C is involved in producing neurotransmitters like dopamine and serotonin that help maintain a happy mood.
High vitamin C levels are associated with improved mood and vitality.
Protein: Protein provides amino acids that are essential for producing mood-regulating neurotransmitters.
A steady supply of protein helps maintain stable blood sugar and sustained energy, supporting a positive mood.
Protein is made up of amino acids, which are the building blocks for neurotransmitters that regulate mood.
Protein helps stabilize blood sugar levels, preventing mood swings caused by energy crashes.
Calcium: Calcium plays a role in releasing neurotransmitters which affect mood and mental function.
Calcium helps maintain proper nerve function, which is essential for mood regulation.
Vitamin C: Vitamin C is a powerful antioxidant that helps protect the brain from oxidative stress.
Vitamin C is needed to produce neurotransmitters like dopamine and serotonin.
Vitamin D: Vitamin D receptors are found throughout the brain, suggesting its importance in brain function and mood.
Vitamin D may help regulate the conversion of tryptophan into serotonin, a neurotransmitter that affects mood.
Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is essential for the production of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe), a compound that helps regulate mood.
Vitamin B12 deficiency has been linked to depression and mood disorders.
Iron: Iron is necessary for producing dopamine, a neurotransmitter involved in mood regulation.
Iron deficiency can lead to fatigue and mood changes due to reduced oxygen transport to the brain.
Magnesium: Magnesium regulates the activity of NMDA receptors involved in mood and emotions.
Magnesium helps activate B vitamins important for stress response and emotional health.
Zinc: Zinc influences the production and action of numerous neurotransmitters and hormones.
Zinc plays a key role in regulating the body's response to stress.
Polyunsaturated Fats: Polyunsaturated fats, especially omega-3s, are important components of brain cell membranes.
Omega-3 fatty acids have anti-inflammatory effects in the brain that may help with mood regulation.
